Subjective: Sore throat for 3 days with fever this morning. Pain is unbearable on swallowing. Preceded by a cough last week, now resolved. Used paracetamol and ibuprofen with poor relief. No shortness of breath or runny nose. Social: Friend recently had a peritonsillar abscess. Request: Concerned about having an abscess and thinks she needs antibiotics.
Objective: Vitals: Temp 38.3Â°C, SpO2 98%. Ears: Left ear normal, air-filled tympanic membrane. Right ear has mild redness in ear canal, otherwise normal. Neck: Small, non-pathological submandibular lymph nodes. Throat: Uvula median. Slightly red pharyngeal arch. Tonsils bilaterally enlarged with some slough, not kissing. No signs of abscess. Lungs: Vesicular breath sounds, no additional sounds.
Assessment: Acute pharyngitis, likely viral etiology. Peritonsillar abscess ruled out.
Plan: Explained likely viral cause and that antibiotics are not indicated. Reassured no signs of abscess. For pain, continue paracetamol up to 4x/day; may add ibuprofen 400mg up to 3x/day. Advised ample fluid intake, cold drinks, and popsicles for symptomatic relief. Safety Netting: Return if becomes much sicker, develops shortness of breath, or is unable to swallow.
